questions.text: 1. A 40-year-old obese female patient presents with severe abdominal pain. On examination, abdominal tenderness is present over the right hypochondrium and epigastrium. Her erect X-ray of the abdomen is given below. What would the histopathological section of the affected organ show?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the x-ray image of the porcelain gall bladder are suggestive of chronic cholecystitis. The histopathology of the affected organ would be showing dystrophic calcifications of the gall bladder.

The porcelain gall bladder is a morphological feature seen in chronic cholecystitis and is characterized by dystrophic calcification. It is a pathologic calcification in which calcium gets deposited at the sites of cell injury and necrosis. 

Other Options:

Option A: Rokitansky–Aschoff sinuses are the outpouchings of the gallbladder mucosa through the gallbladder wall seen in chronic cholecystitis. They can rupture and develop into xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis.

Option B: Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis is characterized by xanthoma cells. These are macrophages that have ingested biliary phospholipids. In this condition, the gallbladder is shrunken, nodular, and has thickened walls. 

Option D: Hydrops of the gallbladder is characterized by clear secretions within an atrophic, obstructed, and dilated gall bladder.

questions.text: 2. A 2-year-old boy is admitted for multiple skin infections. He also has a history of recurrent bouts of infections with catalase-positive microorganisms such as Staphylococcus aureus, Burkholderia, and Aspergillus. The nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction test is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
This patient has chronic granulomatous disease which occurs due to the defect in NADPH oxidase.

The child has had recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms and has a defect in generating oxygen radicals intracellularly in his phagocytic cells (the negative nitroblue tetrazolium test). This interferes with the killing of bacteria by the oxidative burst. 

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is an inherited defect in microbiocidal activity. In this condition, there is a failure in the formation of reactive oxygen species due to defective phagocytes NADPH oxidase. This leads to the phagocytic inability to kill specific microbes.

Patients have recurrent bacterial and fungal infections. The symptoms begin within the first two years of life, affecting the pulmonary, gastrointestinal, skin, and lymphatic drainage of these organs. Nitroblue tetrazolium is used as a diagnostic test.

Other options:

Option A - X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia is characterized by the failure of B-cell maturation. It is associated with mutations in a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase called Bruton tyrosine kinase (Btk). Patients have decreased levels of B cells. They have recurrent infections caused by Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, or Staphylococcus aureus.

Option B - Leukocyte adhesion defect leads to an inability of the leukocytes to migrate to the site of infection. There are two types. Type 1 occurs due to a defect in the β2 chain present in integrins LFA-1 and Mac-1. Type 2 occurs due to the absence of sialyl-Lewis X.  Both of these present with recurrent bacterial infections.

Option C - Job syndrome is characterized by atopic dermatitis, recurrent skin staphylococcal infections, and recurrent pulmonary infections. It is also known as hyper-IgE syndrome.

Pearl PM2352: Chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to the defect in NADPH oxidase. This interferes with the killing of bacteria by oxidative burst. Hence, the patients are at increased risk of infection from catalase-positive bacteria.



 It can be:

* X linked - Defect in one of the membrane-bound components (gp91phox) or

* Autosomal recessive - Cytoplasmic components (p47phox and p67phox)

Diagnosis of CGD includes:

* Nitroblue tetrazolium test - This is the standard for phagocyte oxidase activity measurement. The colorless compound NBT is reduced to blue formazan by the activity of the functional phox enzyme system. Normally, more than 95% of the granulocytes will be positive. The NBT is negative in CGD due to absence of phox enzyme activity.

* Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test - The most accurate diagnostic test for CGD. Normally functioning phagocytic cells oxidize DHR to the strongly fluorescent compound rhodamine which is quantified by flow cytometry.

questions.text: 3. A young man presents with anemia and jaundice. A peripheral smear shows spherical cells without central pallor. The osmotic fragility test is positive. Which of the following RBC indices is likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young male with anemia and jaundice with spherical cells without central pallor on peripheral smear and a positive osmotic fragility test most likely has hereditary spherocytosis. Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) is the index that is seen elevated in this condition.

Hereditary spherocytosis is an autosomal dominant hereditary hemolytic anemia caused by mutations in red blood cell surface proteins like spectrin and ankyrin. This leads to unstable cell membranes, resulting in hemolysis. Symptoms include severe jaundice, fatigue, and an increased risk of gallstones, especially in childhood.

The peripheral smear will show large spherical red blood cells without central pallor which is seen in normal red blood cells. The diagnosis can be confirmed by the acid glycerol lysis test and the eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test.

Smear showing hereditary spherocytosis:



Osmotic fragility refers to the susceptibility of the red blood cells to undergo lysis when placed in hypotonic media. Hereditary spherocytosis is one of the conditions where the osmotic fragility of the red blood cells is characteristically increased.

Osmotic fragility test is used to assess RBC hemolysis when placed in increasing dilutions of saline solution. In the graph, the x-axis represents the saline concentration while the y-axis represents the percentage of red cells that underwent hemolysis.



MCHC represents the average concentration of hemoglobin within the RBC. Due to the decreased cell volume and relatively normal hemoglobin content in hereditary spherocytosis, MCHC is often elevated. This reflects the packing of more hemoglobin into the smaller spherocytes.

Other options:

Option A: MCV reflects the average volume of an RBC. In hereditary spherocytosis, due to the loss of membrane surface area relative to cell volume,  MCV is typically low (microcytic).

Option B: MCH indicates the average amount of hemoglobin per RBC. In hereditary spherocytosis, the hemoglobin content is usually normal or slightly decreased, resulting in a normal or slightly low MCH.

Option D: The packed cell volume in hereditary spherocytosis is decreased as the spherical cells occupy more space and lead to inefficient packing as compared to a biconcave RBC.

questions.text: 4. An 8-year-old boy with a history of fever, colicky abdominal pain, the passage of blood per rectum 10 days ago, has now presented with swelling of knee joints. He also has a non-blanching palpable erythematous rash, seen predominantly on the lower limbs and buttocks. Platelet levels are within normal ranges. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. A skin biopsy is done to reveal the following finding. What is the most likely type of hypersensitivity in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Clinical features along with the antibodies against vessel walls seen in the immunofluorescence study point towards a diagnosis of Henoch Schonlein purpura(IgA vasculitis) which is a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

It is a small vessel vasculitis that occurs due to the IgA immune complex deposition within the wall of the blood vessels. It is commonly seen in children and is characterized by:

* Palpable purpura without thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy

* Arthralgia- commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints

* Abdominal pain

* About half of the patients with HSP develop renal manifestations, which vary from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis.

The skin biopsy will show small vessel vasculitis, with IgA and C3 deposition in the affected organs by immunofluorescence.

In type III hypersensitivity, immune complexes may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating the complement system. The inflammatory reaction causes tissue injury.

The pathogenesis of systemic immune complex disease can be divided into three phases:

* Formation of immune complexes

* Deposition of immune complexes

* Inflammation and tissue injury.

Examples of Type III hypersensitivity reactions,

* Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

* SLE

* Polyarteritis nodosa

* Reactive arthritis

questions.text: 5. A 10-year-old child is brought to the clinic for evaluation for recurrent hemiparesis. The child has also had two episodes of seizures in the last six months. On examination, the child is short-statured. There is associated motor weakness. Laboratory examination shows lactic acidosis, and muscle biopsy appears as shown below with Gomori trichrome stain. What is the likely mode of inheritance of this disorder?
questions.solution:
The given clinical complex is suggestive of mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS). This disease has a mitochondrial inheritance.

 

The patient presents in childhood, with classical features of hemiparesis and hemianopia, suggestive of stroke-like episodes. The histopathology of the muscle biopsy stained with Gomori-trichrome stain shows ragged red fibers. 

 

In mitochondrial inheritance, if the mother is affected and the father is normal, then all their children (both male and female) will be affected. However, children born to an affected father and a normal mother will not be affected.

 

The mitochondrial inheritance pattern is as shown in the image below:



The unique feature of mitochondrial inheritance is maternal inheritance, as the disease is transmitted through the affected mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which is derived from the maternal mitochondria.

 

The ovum contains several mitochondria, while the spermatozoa have very few mitochondria if present. Hence, the mitochondrial DNA of the zygote is entirely derived from the ovum.

 

Therefore, the affected mother transmits the disease to all the offsprings (both male and female), and only the daughters of the affected mother, will further transmit the disease.

MELAS presents with cortical blindness, seizures, migraines with vomiting, short stature, hearing loss, and muscle weakness. Stroke-like episodes, not confined to typical vascular territories, recur and remit, causing progressive neurological decline and dementia.

questions.text: 6. A patient presented to the clinic with the lesions shown in the image below. The pathogenesis of this condition involves the binding of which of the following pairs of viral oncoproteins and target genes?
questions.solution:
The given image shows condyloma acuminata/genital warts, which are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). The pathogenesis of this condition involves binding of the viral oncoproteins E6 and E7 to the target genes p53 and p21, respectively (Option B).

Condyloma acuminata is a benign, sexually transmitted, wart caused by HPV. It commonly occurs due to infection from low-risk HPV serotypes -HPV 6 and HPV 11. High-risk HPV serotypes cause cervical cancer, of which HPV 16 and HPV 18 account for the majority of cases.

The ability of HPV to act as a carcinogen depends on the viral E6 and E7 proteins, which interfere with the activity of the key tumor suppressor proteins, p53 and RB, respectively.

The E7 protein of HPV binds to hypophosphorylated RB (representing active state) and promotes its degradation via the proteasome pathway. It also binds and inhibits cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors p21 and p27.

The E6 protein binds p53 and promotes its degradation. It also upregulates the expression of telomerase, leading to cellular immortalization.

questions.text: 7. A 23-year-old female patient is transfused with 1 unit of Packed red blood cells for anaemia. After 2 hours of transfusion, the patient complains of fever and chills with mild breathlessness. On examination, there are no signs of jaundice, dark urine, or hypotension, and her cardiovascular examinations is unremarkable. What is the mechanism responsible for this blood transfusion reaction?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with complaints of fever, chills, and mild dyspnoea within 2 hours of transfusion of packed red blood cells is suggestive of a febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction. The mechanism responsible for this reaction is antibodies against donor WBC and HLA antigens.

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions occur within 6 hrs of transfusion and are more commonly seen in patients with multiple transfusions and pregnant women. This is the most common type of transfusion reaction.

Management involves the usage of antipyretics and antihistamines. Transfusion should be stopped if the reaction is severe. This reaction can be prevented by the use of leukoreduced products.

Leukoreduction, primarily via leukocyte reduction filters, removes WBCs from blood products to minimize immune reactions. Other methods include saline washing, freezing and deglycerolizing, buffy coat removal, and microaggregate filters.

Other options:

Option A: IgA deficient recipient leads to anaphylactic transfusion reaction. This occurs within seconds to minutes after transfusion and is a severe reaction, so transfusion must be stopped immediately.

Option C: Recipient IgE acting against donor components leading to mast cell activation is seen in allergic/urticarial transfusion reactions. This occurs within 2-3 hrs of transfusion and is managed by stopping the transfusion with aggressive I.V. fluids administration.

Option D:  ABO incompatibility leads to an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction and this can occur from the start of transfusion to 24 hrs after transfusion. This should be managed by stopping the transfusion and with aggressive I.V. fluids administration.

questions.text: 8. A 16-year-old athlete who had a mutation in the gene encoding for myosin-binding protein C was brought dead to casualty. Which among the following is the most likely histopathological feature seen in the above condition?

choices.text: Diffuse, mononuclear, lymphocytic infiltration in myocardial tissue

questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and mutation in the gene encoding for myosin-binding protein C are suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The most likely histological feature in this condition is the haphazard disarray of myocytes or myofiber disarray.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by myocardial hypertrophy and reduced function of the left ventricular myocardium leading to abnormal diastolic function.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is primarily caused by mutations in genes encoding myosin-binding protein C or beta myosin heavy chain. Symptoms include dyspnea, fatigue, chest pain, presyncope, syncope, and palpitation, though many are asymptomatic.

 HCM is a leading cause of sudden cardiac death in young adults. Key features are massive myocardial dilatation without ventricular dilatation, often presenting as asymmetric septal hypertrophy, which can compress the left ventricular cavity into a banana-like shape.

The most important histologic feature of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy are:

* Massive myocyte hypertrophy, with transverse myocytes size greater than 40 µm (normal size approximately 15 µm) 

* Haphazard disarray of bundles of, individual myocytes, and contractile elements termed as myofiber disarray

* Interstitial and replacement fibrosis

The image given below is a histologic section of cardiac muscle showing myocyte disarray and extreme hypertrophy:



Other options:

Option A: Contraction band necrosis can be seen in reperfusion injury after myocardial infarction (MI). It is also a histological feature seen in takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Histology showing irreversibly injured myocytes with contraction band necrosis and intensely eosinophilic bands of hypercontracted sarcomeres is shown below.



Option C: Ninja star nuclei in myocytes are seen in dilated cardiomyopathy.



Option D: Biopsy showing lymphocytic infiltration in myocardial tissue is suggestive of myocarditis. Viruses are the most common causes among the infectious causes of myocarditis. Endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis and it shows diffuse, mononuclear, lymphocytic infiltration as shown below.

questions.text: 9. A 45-year-old man comes to the hospital with complaints of difficulty breathing. Chest X-Ray shows "eggshell" calcification. Histopathology of the lung shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's radiological and histopathological features are seen in silicosis.

Eggshell calcification refers to the fine rim of calcification seen at the periphery of a mass (usually a lymph node)

Silicotic nodules are characterized by concentrically arranged hyalinized collagen fibers surrounding an amorphous center in the hilar lymph nodes and the upper zones of the lungs.

questions.text: 10. An MRI of a female patient with new-onset seizures revealed a large, ring-enhancing mass with central necrosis and surrounding edema, crossing the corpus callosum into both frontal lobes. Subsequently, she underwent surgical resection of the mass. Grossly, it was a grayish-white solid tumor with yellowish areas of necrosis, with interspersed areas of hemorrhages. Histopathology findings are shown below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with histopathological findings is strongly suggestive of glioblastoma or grade IV astrocytoma.

It affects people usually in the sixth or seventh decade. These tumors may arise de novo or may result from a malignant transformation of lower-grade astrocytomas. Mutations of isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH), PTEN, and epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene are implicated in the pathogenesis.

They preferentially spread along the condensed white matter tracts such as corticospinal tracts and corpus callosum and can give rise to the butterfly glioma, involving the contralateral hemisphere. 

Clinically, patients present with headaches, seizures due to raised intracranial pressure, or focal neurologic deficits, depending upon the site involved. 

Grossly, glioblastomas are found to infiltrate the brain tissue and are poorly delineated. They have grayish tumor cells with central yellowish necrosis and multiple areas of hemorrhages. Microscopically, they are composed of poorly differentiated pleomorphic astrocytic cells with nuclear atypia and high mitotic activity. Necrosis and florid microvascular proliferation are characteristic. They exhibit pseudopalisading—dense arrangement of tumor cells lining up around the foci of tumor necrosis.

Radiologically, glioblastomas appear as a large ring-enhancing heterogeneous mass with central necrosis and surrounding edema that crosses the corpus callosum into both frontal lobes. The surrounding edema may be interspersed with infiltrating tumor cells. The tumor may show partial or complete enhancement on contrast study. 

Standard treatment includes surgery followed by a combination of radiotherapy and chemotherapy with temozolomide following surgical resection. Bevacizumab, which is a vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) antibody, may be used in the treatment of recurrent glioblastoma.

Option B: Craniopharyngioma - These are slow-growing, hypothalamic suprasellar tumors arising from vestigial remnants of the Rathke pouch. They often encroach on the optic chiasm or cranial nerves, and not infrequently they bulge into the floor of the third ventricle and base of the brain.

Option C: Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumors of adults that arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid and are usually attached to the dura. They are found along any of the external surfaces of the brain as well as within the ventricular system, where they arise from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus. The most common histological pattern seen is meningothelial pattern, where clusters of epithelioid cells with indiscernible cell membranes are present.

questions.text: 11. An elderly male is being evaluated for bone pain. Laboratory findings show elevated serum alkaline phosphatase and urinary hydroxyproline but normal serum calcium and phosphorus levels. The histopathological slide from the lesion is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathological slide are suggestive of Paget's disease or Osteitis deformans. It is a disorder of increased, but disordered and structurally unsound, bone mass.

Histology of Paget's disease of the bone showing a jigsaw-like pattern produced by unusually prominent cement lines, which join haphazardly oriented units of lamellar bone

Pathogenesis: Mutations in the SQSTM1 gene increase the activity of NF-κB, which increases osteoclast activity.Three sequential phases:

* initial osteolytic stage

* a mixed osteoclastic-osteoblastic stage

* a final burned-out quiescent osteosclerotic stage

The onset is in late adulthood (average age at diagnosis, 70 years).The axial skeleton or proximal femur is involved in up to 80% of the cases.

*  Enlargement of the craniofacial skeleton:  leontiasis ossea or lion face

* Weakened Pagetic bone: invagination of the skull base (platybasia) 

* Chalk stick-type fractures in the long bones of the lower extremities.

The pathological hallmark is a mosaic pattern of lamellar bone, seen in the sclerotic phase.

Other options:

Option A: Osteopetrosis has impaired bone resorption, normal ALP and has diffuse sclerotic bone in histology.

Option C: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumour with malignant osteoblasts with osteoid matrix.

questions.text: 12. A 4-year-old girl with influenza is brought to the casualty with complaints of disorientation and right upper quadrant pain. Her parents had given her some over-the-counter medications for her fever. Her liver enzymes are elevated. Which of the following pathologic findings is likely in this patient?

choices.text: Schistocytes on peripheral smear of the blood
Marked microvesicular steatosis of the liver
Neutrophilic infiltrate of the gall bladder mucosa

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of influenza and over-the-counter medication use which was probably aspirin now presents with confusion and right upper quadrant pain. This should raise concerns for Reye's syndrome. The liver biopsy in Reye's syndrome will show marked microvesicular steatosis.

Reye's syndrome is an acute illness, encountered exclusively in children <15 years. Its onset usually follows upper respiratory tract infections. The actual cause is unknown, although viral agents and salicylates (aspirin) have been implicated.

Generalized mitochondrial dysfunction causes structural and functional changes in the mitochondria of the liver, brain, and muscle. This leads to an enlarged liver (with minimal or no jaundice), vomiting, progressive central nervous system damage, hepatic injury, and hypoglycemia.

Extensive accumulation of fat droplets within hepatocytes (microvesicular steatosis) can be seen in histopathology. Extra-hepatic changes include fatty changes of renal tubular cells, cerebral edema, and neuronal degeneration of the brain.

The image given below shows microvesicular steatosis of liver.



Note: Aspirin is generally contraindicated in children, except in the treatment of Kawasaki disease and juvenile idiopathic arthritis. 

Other options:

Option A: Schistocytes on the peripheral smear can be seen in Hemolytic uremic syndrome due to shearing effect of platelet thrombi on RBCs.

Option C: Diffuse axonal injury is seen after traumatic head injury and not in Reye's syndrome.

Option D: Neutrophilic infiltrate in the gall bladder can be seen in acute cholecystitis. However, this condition is not usually seen in children, and the presence of confusion with raised liver enzymes in a setting of a known influenza infection should raise concerns for Reye's syndrome.

questions.text: 13. After an episode of viral hepatitis, which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the regeneration of the lost hepatocytes?

choices.text: Decreased apoptosis at G1-M part of cell cycle
Hepatocyte recruitment from G0 to enter cell cycle
Hepatocytes undergoing terminal differentiation as they exit the cell cycle

questions.solution:
Liver parenchyma is an example of stable tissue. It is made up of cells that are normally in the G0 phase (quiescent) of the cell cycle and are not proliferating. However, they are capable of entering the cell cycle and proliferating in response to injury.

Different tissues have different intrinsic proliferative capacity, which determines their ability to repair themselves. 

Labile tissues - cells are constantly being lost and must be continually replaced by new cells that are derived from tissue stem cells (option C). These tissues can readily regenerate after injury as long as the pool of stem cells is preserved.

* Hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow

* Basal layers of many surface epithelia, such as squamous epithelia of the skin, oral cavity

* Cuboidal epithelia of the ducts draining exocrine organs e.g., salivary glands, biliary tract

* Columnar epithelium of the gastrointestinal tract, uterus, and fallopian tubes

* Transitional epithelium of the urinary tract

Stable tissues - made up of cells that are normally in the G0 stage of the cell cycle and hence not proliferating, but they are capable of dividing in response to injury.

* Parenchyma of most solid organs, such as liver, kidney, and pancreas

* Endothelial cells, fibroblasts, and smooth muscle cells

Permanent tissues - The cells in these tissues are considered to be terminally differentiated and nonproliferative in postnatal life. Injury to these tissues is irreversible and results in a scar, because the cells cannot regenerate.

* Majority of neurons

* Cardiac muscle cells

Other options:

Option A: Decreased apoptosis would not lead to the regeneration of the lost hepatocytes.

Option D: Hepatocytes do not undergo terminal differentiation as they exit the cell cycle since they are stable tissue.

questions.text: 14. A 34 year old male with a history of undergoing surgery for undescended testes presented with a firm, non-tender scrotal mass. It was possible to get above the swelling. USG showed a homogenous,hypoechoic intratesticular mass. The mass was surgically removed and the patient was suspected to have metastasis based on the histopathology report. What is the most common route of metastasis in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical case points to a diagnosis of seminoma which is the commonest testicular tumor in patients with a history of cryptorchidism. Seminomas metastasize mainly via the lymphatics and hematogenous spread is uncommon.

The lymphatic drainage of the testes is to the para-aortic lymph nodes near the origin of the gonadal vessels. The contralateral para-aortic lymph nodes are sometimes involved by tumor spread, but the inguinal lymph nodes are affected only if the scrotal skin is involved.

Seminoma is the most common germ cell tumor (50% of GCTs), peaking in the fourth decade. It's the testicular equivalent of ovarian dysgerminoma or pineal germinoma. Grossly, it's a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated mass without hemorrhage or necrosis.



Histologically, it shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and a central nucleus with a prominent nucleolus ("fried-egg appearance"), poorly demarcated by fibrous septa containing lymphocytes. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, PLAP and podoplanin and negative for cytokeratin.



The USG image shows a mass that is homogenous, hypoechoic compared to surrounding stroma, and arising from within testes.



Clinically, seminoma presents as a painless testicular enlargement, often found on ultrasound. Metastatic symptoms are rare. Sonography is mandatory. Pre-orchiectomy, tumor markers (elevated in up to 50%) are crucial for follow-up.

Definitive treatment is inguinal orchiectomy. Post-surgery, surveillance with CT and tumor markers monitors for metastasis or relapse. Histopathology guides subsequent radiotherapy or chemotherapy if needed.

On examination, massive splenomegaly was found. There was no lymphadenopathy. His peripheral smear is as shown below. What is the drug of choice for this malignancy?

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the findings of leukemic cells with fine hair-like projections in the peripheral smear are suggestive of hairy cell leukemia. Cladribine is the drug of choice for the treatment of hairy cell leukemia.

Hairy cell leukemia is responsive to chemotherapy with interferon α, pentostatin, and cladribine. However, cladribine, a purine analogue is the preferred drug of choice as complete remission with cladribine occurs clinically in the majority of patients and long-term disease-free survival is frequent. Cladribine is administered daily for 7 days by continuous intravenous infusion.

Chemotherapy-refractory patients have responded to vemurafenib, a BRAF inhibitor. Splenectomy is often associated with prolonged remission.

Most patients present with symptoms of cytopenias or splenomegaly. Dry tap is obtained upon performing bone marrow aspiration due to HCL-induced marrow fibrosis and the interlocking cell borders of hairy cells (do not confuse with myelofibrosis).

CD11c, CD25, CD103, CD123 are the characteristic immunophenotypes diagnostic of Hairy cell leukemia. Pan-B markers such as CD19, CD20, and CD22 can also test positive for Hairy cell leukemia.

There is an increased incidence of atypical mycobacterial infections (Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) in hairy cell leukemia. This is possibly related to frequent unexplained monocytopenia. Out of the atypical mycobacteria, Mycobacterium kansasii infection is a unique feature of hairy-cell leukemia.

Annexin A1 on bone marrow specimens has been shown to have 100% sensitivity and specificity in differentiating hairy cell leukemia from other B cell malignancies. Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) stain is an important tool in the clinical diagnosis of hairy cell leukemia and yields positive results in ≈95% of the cases.

Hairy cells on Wright-stained peripheral blood smear is an important diagnostic finding. However, these can be seen in other B-cell disorders also. Typical hairy cells are mononuclear cells with abundant pale blue-grey agranular cytoplasm with elongated (hairy) projections.

questions.text: 16. A patient with aplastic anemia undergoes bone marrow transplantation. Within 2 weeks, he presents with complaints of bloody diarrhea. Upon further examination, he was found to have jaundice and blistering rashes on the skin. What is the possible mechanism behind the patient's current clinical picture?

choices.text: Immune cells of the host attacking transplanted tissue
Preformed antibodies of the host attacking transplanted tissue

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). The possible mechanism behind the patient's current clinical picture is transplanted cells attacking host tissues.

Transfusion of irradiated RBCs prevents the incidence of GVHD associated with the transfusion.

GVHD occurs when immunologically competent cells or their precursors are transplanted into immunologically compromised recipients. The transferred cells recognize the alloantigens in the host and attack host tissues. It is seen most commonly during hematopoietic stem cell transplantation but may also occur following the transplantation of solid organs. 

GVHD may be of two types: acute and chronic.

Acute GVHD occurs within days to weeks after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. It mainly involves the immune system and the epithelia of the skin (in the form of generalized rash), liver (in the form of jaundice), and intestines (in the form of bloody diarrhea). But the affected tissues are not heavily infiltrated by lymphocytes.

Chronic GVHD can follow acute GVHD or emerge subtly. Patients experience extensive skin damage resembling systemic sclerosis, cholestatic jaundice, and esophageal strictures. Thymic involution, lymph node lymphocyte depletion, and recurrent, life-threatening infections are common. Autoimmunity may also develop due to grafted CD4+ helper T cells stimulating host B cells to produce autoantibodies.

While donor T-cell depletion via irradiation can prevent GVHD, it carries risks like tumor recurrence, graft failures, and EBV-related B-cell lymphoma.

questions.text: 18. A 40-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with difficulty in breathing. He had puffiness around the eyes, pitting edema of the lower limbs, and ascites. His 24-hour urine protein shows a protein level of 4 g/24h. CT chest shows a saddle embolus. What is the cause of this patient's CT findings?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome complicated by pulmonary embolism. Thrombo-embolic complications in nephrotic syndrome are due to the loss of endogenous anticoagulants such as antithrombin III in the urine.

Nephrotic syndrome is a condition that occurs due to damage in the glomerular capillary walls thereby leading to increased capillary permeability to plasma proteins. The manifestations and the mechanisms of nephrotic syndrome are:

* Massive proteinuria (>3.5 grams) as a result of leakage in the barrier formed by glomerular basement membrane, endothelium, and visceral epithelial cells.

* Hypoalbuminemia (albumin <3g/dL) occurs as a consequence of proteinuria. Also, increased catabolism of the kidney contributes to hypoalbuminemia. 

* Generalized edema is seen. The edema is soft and pitting seen in periorbital and dependent portions of the body. It occurs as a result of decreased intravascular colloid osmotic pressure and other factors like sodium and water retention lead to edema. 

* Hyperlipidemia occurs following the increased synthesis of lipoproteins, lipid particles, and decreased catabolism of lipids.

* Lipiduria is due to leakage of lipids through the glomerular capillary wall.

Increased susceptibility to infections is another complication. It is due to the loss of immunoglobulins in the urine. The CT image below depicts a large pulmonary embolism at the pulmonary artery bifurcation (saddle embolism).

questions.text: 19. A 45-year-old female patient presents with complaints of a firm neck swelling associated with dysphagia for the past 3 months. A blood workup shows increased serum calcitonin levels. She reveals that her mother had similar complaints. A biopsy is taken to confirm the diagnosis which is given below. Which mutation is this condition associated with?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from medullary thyroid carcinoma. RET mutation is associated with this condition.

Medullary thyroid carcinoma, a neuroendocrine tumor from parafollicular C cells, secretes calcitonin. While mostly sporadic, some of cases link to familial multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes: MEN 2A and 2B. 

RET mutation is key in familial and sporadic cancers. Sporadic medullary thyroid carcinoma patients often have a neck mass, dysphagia, or hoarseness. Familial syndromes present with thyroid-specific symptoms or endocrine neoplasms in other organs.

Histopathology shows polygonal to spindle-shaped cells which form nests, trabeculae, or follicles. Amyloid deposits that are derived from the altered calcitonin molecules are present in the stroma. Calcitonin in the tumor cells and stroma is easily demonstratable by immunohistochemistry.

20. A 30-year-old primigravida at 24 weeks presents with decreased fetal movements. During the consultation, she collapses because of low blood pressure. An ultrasound showed fetal demise. Investigations revealed low platelets, increased fibrin degradation products, and prolonged bleeding and clotting time. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

* It occurs due to tissue factor release and endothelial injury.

* It is associated with Waterhouse-Friderichson syndrome.

* During septic shock, this condition occurs due to TNF and interleukin 1.

* It is also known as consumptive coagulopathy.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a primigravida is highly suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation. All the given statements (1, 2, 3, and 4) are true regarding DIC.

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a thrombo-hemorrhagic disorder in which there is widespread clotting in the body. The most common causes of DIC are obstetric complications like amniotic fluid embolisms and retained products of conception. DIC presents with fetal demise, hypotension, thrombocytopenia, and deranged bleeding and clotting times.

DIC results due to endothelial injury or release of tissue factor and other procoagulants. TNF (tissue necrosis factor) is an important mediator of endothelial injury. It can promote the expression of tissue factor on endothelial cells and also stimulate the adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium, causing further damage and clotting (statement 1). In septic shock, TNF and interleukin-1 (IL-1) are important causative factors of DIC (statement 3).

These factors result in the occlusion of the microvasculature by thrombi. Large-scale clotting leads to the consumption of platelets and clotting factors. Hence, it is also called consumptive coagulopathy (statement 4). 

The clinical diagnosis is supported by the following laboratory findings:

* low platelet count

* prolonged bleeding time

* prolonged PT/aPTT

* elevated fibrin degradation products

* elevated D-dimer

Two common named syndromes associated with DIC:

* Waterhouse-Friderichson syndrome caused by meningococcal septicemia. It can result in microthrombi that block the adrenal vasculature and ultimately result in adrenal hemorrhage due to DIC (statement 2).

* Kasabach-Merritt syndrome is a type of DIC that is seen with giant hemangiomas. Recurrent bleeding and clotting in these fragile vessels results in DIC.

Pearl PM0324: Causes of Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute, subacute, or chronic thrombohemorrhagic disorder occurring as a secondary complication in a variety of diseases. It is characterized by the activation of the coagulation sequence that leads to the formation of microthrombi throughout the microcirculation of the body. As a consequence of the thrombotic diathesis, there is a consumption of platelets, fibrin, and coagulation factors and, secondarily, activation of fibrinolytic mechanisms.

Pearl PM0317: Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

 Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

Parameter Uses
Prothrombin Time (PT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the extrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal PT is 11–13 seconds.
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the intrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal aPTT is 25–35 seconds. A relatively rare cause of prolonged aPTT is the presence of antibodies against coagulation plasma proteins called inhibitors. It can be seen due to the following reasons: Hemophilia A and B patients receiving clotting factors to control their bleeding episodes, Pregnancy, Autoimmune diseases, Malignancies (lymphoma, prostate cancer), and Dermatologic conditions.
Thrombin time (TT) It is used for testing the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin and depends on adequate fibrinogen levels. 
Bleeding time (BT) It is the time taken for a standardized skin puncture to stop bleeding. It tests the ability of blood vessels to constrict and platelets to form a hemostatic plug. 
Fibrin degradation products (FDPs) They are used to assess the fibrinolytic activity, and they are increased in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
